title: Fasting and its Challenges
content: Women may have a harder time fasting, and tips for those who are struggling. There may be some evolutionary reasons why women struggle more with fasting. For people who struggle, it's suggested to start with 18 hr fasts with 6 hr eating window, then move to 1 meal per day, and then a 36 hour fast. It's important to check glucose levels to get some insight into why energy might be so low. When fasting, it's important to not push through if you feel unwell, and to drink more water than you think. When you fast you excrete sodium at a higher rate and food has water in it so you need to compensate for that.

title: Fasting in Adolescents
content: There may be certain situations where fasting might make sense in adolescents, such as obese kids, T2 diabetes, NAFLD. But one has to be very careful as adolescents are still growing and there is a critical window during which deprivation of food can be potentially harmful.

title: Learning and Retaining Information
content: Tips for learning and retaining large amounts of new information include writing it down with a pen, studying in small groups where you can quiz each other on conceptual info, and ensuring adequate sleep as the hippocampus is sensitive to sleep deprivation. For diet, anything that is going to minimize swings in glucose is preferred. Fasting and cognitive performance is unclear, but there is anecdotal evidence of more mental clarity. Exogenous ketones could potentially help.

title: Training for Performance versus Longevity
content: Training differs when optimizing for performance versus longevity. For performance, the focus is on pushing the body to its limits to achieve maximum output. For longevity, the focus shifts to maintaining overall health and functionality of the body over a longer period of time.

title: Effects of Testosterone and Growth Hormone
content: Taking testosterone and growth hormone can affect performance versus longevity. These hormones can enhance performance by increasing muscle mass and strength, but their long-term effects on longevity are not well understood.

title: Health Obsession as a Negative Stressor
content: It is possible to obsess so much about your health that it becomes a negative stressor. While it's important to be proactive about health, obsessing over it can lead to unnecessary stress and anxiety, which can negatively impact health.

title: Proactive Health Tests
content: There are several tests worth doing if you want to be proactive about your health. However, the specific tests would depend on individual health concerns and risks.

title: Beneficial Supplements
content: There are certain supplements that could be beneficial to health. However, the specific supplements would depend on individual health needs and concerns.

title: Fasting for Athletes
content: Fasting might be used in athletes for manipulating testosterone levels and for injury recovery/regeneration. However, testosterone levels tend to plummet after a 7 day fast. The literature on inflammation and fasting clearly shows a reduction in inflammation. Additionally, everybody almost without exception notices that little aches and pains just vanish. When fasting, top end endurance is lower and more recovery time is needed in between sets. An alternative strategy for athletes could be Hypocaloric feeding with creatine supplementation, where you’re eating 750 to a 1,000 calories per day. You still could get enough glycogen replacement which is good because that’s probably where the athletes are hurt the most with a water-only fast combined with training volume.

title: Longevity and mTOR
content: The mechanistic target of rapamycin is a very potent nutrient sensing protein aggregate within cells. Transient inhibition of this nutrient sensing machinery seems to produce a really impressive longevity phenotype. The easiest way to demonstrate the longevity benefits of inhibiting mTOR is with the drug called rapamycin. Fasting is another way to transiently turn down mTOR. More drugs are in development for mTOR inhibition.

title: Trying New Drugs or Fasting
content: Before trying a new drug or type of fasting, it's important to see convincing animal data, some sort of human clinical evidence of the manifestation, and understand the mechanistic reason this effect is happening. It's also important to identify the range of risk and make sure it’s not too high where the benefit may be significant.

title: Health Obsession and Stress
content: It is possible to obsess so much about health that it becomes a negative stressor. Finding a balance between not stressing about health but also not being totally negligent is important.

title: Proactive Health Tests
content: If you want to be proactive about your health, it's useful to know your APOE genotype. You can’t change it, but you can get insight into your risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Exercise plays an incredible role in maintaining hippocampal volume, maintaining blood flow to the brain, and controlling metabolic circulating factors that play an important role in the preservation of cognition. Other tests that might be useful include Lp(a) levels, which is the leading cause of inherited risk for cardiovascular disease, and APOE test. Liquid biopsies for cancer screening are also becoming commercially viable.

title: Continuous Glucose Monitoring
content: Continuous Glucose Monitoring is an important measurement. It would be incredibly instructive for people to walk around and understand how their glucose levels change with respect to what they eat, how poorly they sleep, when they sleep poorly, and how much their cortisol levels go up, etc. Glucose levels can spike with stress, informing the need for meditation.

title: Supplements for Health
content: About 80% of the population is probably very deficient in EPA and DHA, two very important omega-3 fatty acids that we get from fish. Some people who eat enough fish don’t need to supplement that. Data are reasonably compelling that having high levels of EPA and DHA in your tissue membranes is beneficial when supplemented to the right level.

title: Training for Performance vs Longevity
content: Optimizing for longevity compared to being the best at something changes how one does things. For example, maximizing the weight one could bench probably puts them at undue risk. It’s better to optimize around stability and long-term strength and pliability and very little to do with how much weight one is moving.

title: Testosterone and Growth Hormone Effects
content: Testosterone is in some ways the easiest drug to give somebody because more is always better in terms of performance. However, having too much testosterone in your body is probably counterproductive for longevity. Growth hormone, while having enormous performance benefits in the short term, probably comes with a bit more risk than we want for longevity.
